awd_titl_txt: SI2-SSE: Software for Semiconductor and Electrochemical Interfaces (SSEI)
awd_abstract_narration:
The importance of materials interfaces is apparent when considering key industrial segments such as the microelectronics, chemical, energy, and biomedical industries. Interfaces and surfaces often control the properties of materials and the interface structure and chemistry are one of the most important, yet least understood, aspects of materials synthesis and functionalization. Materials interfaces come in a broad variety, ranging from solid/solid interfaces in semiconductor hetero-structures to solid/liquid interfaces in electrochemistry and biomaterials, and solid/vapor interfaces in chemical vapor deposition and free-standing 2D materials. Despite their diversity, all interfaces present a common set of challenges for computational studies. This project will develop a sustainable software package that enables ab initio simulations of materials interfaces in various environments that extends the current state of the art by adding functionality and increasing performance. The software tools will impact the development and the design of novel materials that broadly benefit society in the fields of catalysis, electrochemistry, battery technologies, and electronic devices.


The goal of this project is to develop a comprehensive and sustainable Software for Semiconductor and Electrochemical Interfaces (SSEI) that provides various continuum models and couples them to ab initio simulations. The SSEI package will enable an efficient and accurate description of a wide variety of materials interfaces that are important for application in energy technologies, corrosion research, electronic devices, and 2D materials. The SSEI is based on the VASPsol module developed by the PI and will be developed primarily for direct use as a module in VASP. For future extension of the software to other DFT codes, the project will provide a portable software interface and detailed documentation. The software design goals are to develop SSEI into (i) a sustainable scientific tool, (ii) significantly extend its functionality to nonlinear models and arbitrary electrostatic boundary conditions, and (iii) increase its performance. These complementary goals will be achieved through an expansion of the developer and user base, a transition to portable software interfaces and data structures, and the addition of modular algorithms for functionality and performance enhancements. All developments will make extensive use of object-oriented programming principles and software design patterns to speed up the development process and aid maintainability. The SSEI package provides the predictive tools for materials interfaces that have the potential to transform the use of ab initio methods to advance our fundamental knowledge and enable the design and optimization of materials interfaces for better catalysts, battery electrodes, electronic junctions, and corrosion resistance.

This project is supported by the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure in the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering and the Division of Materials Research in the Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This award from the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure in the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering and the Division of Materials Research in the Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences supported fundamental research and method developments for materials interfaces. Interfaces and surfaces often control the properties of materials. The structure and chemistry of interfaces are one of the most important yet least understood aspects of materials synthesis and functionalization. Addressing these knowledge gaps was the overarching objective of the project. The team of Professor Richard Hennig at the University of Florida developed computational algorithms and software tools for predicting surface structures and calculating their properties, combining first-principle methods with continuum solvation and electrolyte models.

The Intellectual Merit outcomes include the development of a software module for the ab-initio description of materials interfaces with electrolytes under applied potentials. Coupling this open-source module to the most widely used density-functional theory code increases the impact of the work on the broad community. This software module is generally applicable to various materials surfaces and electrochemical interfaces. The software, including documentation and examples, is freely available as open-source cyberinfrastructure for the broad materials research community.

First, implementing the Poisson-Boltzmann electrolyte model enables accurate electrochemical calculations for materials interfaces at applied potentials. Next, the generalization of the linear Poisson solvation model to a non-linear model describes the dielectric saturation of the permittivity at high local electric fields. Finally, the extension to a non-linear Poisson-Boltzmann electrolyte model provides the ionic shielding at large applied potentials beyond the validity range of the linear approximation. The model also accounts for finite-volume effects of the electrolyte ions, which removes unphysically large concentrations that can occur near electrode surfaces. Comparing the predictions with experimental data validates the approach. Optimizing the electrolyte model parameters enables an accurate description of experimental solvation energies. The application of the method to transition-metal carbides and nitrides demonstrated that first-principles methods can predict the electrochemical synthesis conditions of two-dimensional M2Xenes phases from their M2AX bulk phase precursors.

In addition, implementing an electrostatic correction method into the workflow for defect calculations enables the accurate determination of charge transition levels in semiconductors. Applying this approach to two-dimensional molybdenum di-sulfide and tungsten di-selenide shows that dopants can form complexes with sulfur vacancies which can quench the doping. For another class of 2D materials that includes phosphorene and tin sulfide, the method showed that defects strongly affect their optical properties, leading to sizable Frank-Condon and Stokes shifts.

The Broader Impact outcomes include establishing computational frameworks for the structure and composition prediction of materials interfaces and their electrochemical properties. The project contributed to training the next generation of computational researchers to develop future cyberinfrastructure. The project supported several undergraduate and graduate students in developing computational algorithms and the study of materials surfaces, 2D materials, and electrochemical interfaces. In addition, the team developed an outreach activity and experiment kit on electrical resistivity. The kit was used in several outreach events for Florida middle and high school students. The team used this experience and the students? feedback to refine the experiment kit, which will become part of the lending library of experiments at the University of Florida.

 


Last Modified: 04/18/2023
Modified by: Richard G Hennig
